title: R41107
content: Negotiating parties of the proposed Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) have until May 1, 2013, to sign the agreement. The ACTA will enter into force after the sixth instrument of ratification is deposited. Mexico signed the ACTA on July 11, 2012, requiring ratification in the Mexican Congress. The European Parliament voted against the ACTA on July 4, 2012, preventing the EU and its member states from joining. On July 11, 2012, Mexico signed the ACTA, which requires ratification in the Mexican Congress. The European Parliament voted against the ACTA on July 4, 2012, preventing the EU and its member states from joining. Several EU member states suspended or did not initiate domestic adoption of the ACTA amid protests for Internet free speech. The European Commission placed the ACTA ratification process on hold on February 22, 2012, and submitted the agreement to the European Court of Justice for compatibility with EU law. On January 25, 2012, the European Union and 22 EU member states signed the ACTA, with five member states not signing due to procedural issues. On October 1, 2011, several countries including Australia, Canada, Japan, Korea, Morocco, New Zealand, Singapore, and the United States signed the ACTA. The European Union and 22 member states signed the agreement on January 25, 2012, with five member states not signing due to procedural issues. Representatives from the EU, Mexico, and Switzerland expressed support for the agreement. The final version of the agreement text was publicly released in May 2011. The ACTA negotiating parties affirmed their support for the Agreement and preparations to sign it promptly. The final version of the agreement text was released in May 2011 after nearly three years of negotiations. The proposed Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement aims to combat intellectual property rights infringement and build on the standards set by the WTO Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights. The ACTA, negotiated by several countries including the United States, aims to enhance IPR protection and enforcement, particularly in the digital environment. It focuses on trademarks and copyrights enforcement, with provisions for civil, border, and criminal enforcement against willful trademark counterfeiting or copyright piracy on a commercial scale. The ACTA focuses on enforcing trademarks and copyrights, with provisions for civil, border, and criminal enforcement against willful trademark counterfeiting or copyright piracy on a commercial scale. It also includes enhanced enforcement practices and international cooperation. The negotiation concluded in October 2010, with countries having until May 1, 2013, to sign the agreement. All negotiating parties, except Mexico and Switzerland, have signed it, and domestic ratification procedures are underway. The negotiation for the ACTA concluded in October 2010, with countries given until May 1, 2013, to sign the agreement. All negotiating parties, except Mexico and Switzerland, have signed it. The idea of negotiating the ACTA was conceived in 2006 by the United States and Japan to combat counterfeiting and piracy. The ACTA negotiation began in 2006 to combat counterfeiting and piracy. In 2007, interested parties including Canada, the European Union, Japan, Switzerland, and the United States initiated talks. By 2008, more countries joined the negotiations, aiming to conclude the agreement by the end of the year. After 11 rounds of negotiations, the final round in October 2010 in Japan resolved most issues. The ACTA negotiation began in 2006 to combat counterfeiting and piracy, involving countries like Canada, the European Union, Japan, Switzerland, and the United States. By October 2011, Australia, Canada, Japan, Korea, Morocco, New Zealand, Singapore, and the United States signed the ACTA, with others expressing support for the agreement. On January 25, 2012, the European Union and 22 member states signed the ACTA, followed by Mexico on July 11, 2012. The signatories aim to ratify the agreement promptly for it to enter into force after the sixth instrument of approval is deposited. The ACTA agreement will enter into force after the sixth instrument of ratification is deposited by participants. Countries are now going through their domestic approval processes, with the USTR negotiating it as an executive agreement for the U.S. No country has deposited an instrument of approval yet, and it is unclear when the United States will do so. The ACTA agreement does not need congressional approval unless it requires changes to U.S. law. The USTR believes it aligns with existing U.S. law and does not need new legislation. The European Commission negotiated on behalf of EU member states, but the European Parliament voted against ACTA in 2012. EU member states are now going through national ratification processes. On July 4, 2012, the European Parliament voted against the ACTA, preventing the EU and its member states from joining. Several EU countries halted or postponed their adoption of the ACTA due to protests for Internet free speech. The European Commission paused the ratification process and sent the agreement to the European Court of Justice for review. There is a chance the European Commission may revive the ACTA after the court ruling. Some participants, like the US, EU, and Switzerland, argue that implementing the ACTA won't require changes to their laws. The European Parliament voted against the ACTA on July 4, 2012, preventing the EU and its member states from joining. The European Commission sent the agreement to the European Court of Justice for review, with the possibility of reviving the ACTA after the court ruling. Some countries may need to pass new laws to implement the enforcement standards of the ACTA, including granting customs officials ex-officio authority and providing legal remedies for circumventing technological protection measures. The ACTA focuses on trademark infringement, copyright piracy, and legal remedies for circumventing TPM. Canada incorporated WIPO Internet treaties into domestic law with copyright bill C-11. Economically advanced countries involved in ACTA negotiations view IPR-based industries as vital to their economies. The ACTA focuses on trademark infringement, copyright piracy, and legal remedies for circumventing TPM. Economically advanced countries involved in the negotiations consider IPR-based industries vital to their economies. The ACTA establishes a legal framework for IPR enforcement, increased international cooperation, and enhanced enforcement measures. Key provisions include the nature and scope of the agreement, implementation of WIPO Internet treaties, and free trade agreements with the United States. The ACTA focuses on trademark infringement, copyright piracy, and legal remedies for circumventing TPM. It establishes a legal framework for IPR enforcement, international cooperation, and enhanced measures. Key provisions include the nature and scope of the agreement, implementation of WIPO Internet treaties, and free trade agreements with the United States. The chapter of the ACTA outlines provisions for flexibility in implementing IPR enforcement, notes the application of TRIPS Agreement principles, and specifies that obligations do not extend to intellectual property not protected under domestic laws. It includes sections on general enforcement obligations, civil and criminal enforcement, border measures, and enforcement in the digital environment. The legal framework chapter of the ACTA requires Parties to enforce intellectual property obligations even for IP not protected under domestic laws. It includes sections on general enforcement obligations, civil enforcement, border measures, criminal enforcement, and enforcement in the digital environment, emphasizing expeditious and deterrent remedies while avoiding trade barriers. Civil enforcement mandates each Party to provide civil judicial procedures for IPR enforcement. The civil enforcement section of the ACTA requires Parties to provide civil judicial procedures for IPR enforcement, including issuing injunctions, ordering damages, recovery of costs, and attorneys' fees. The ACTA's civil enforcement section mandates judicial procedures for IPR enforcement, including injunctions, damages, cost recovery, and attorney fees. It also allows for the destruction of infringing goods, orders provisional measures like seizures, and requires the infringer to provide information on the infringement. Parties may exclude patents and undisclosed information from this section. The civil enforcement section of the ACTA mandates judicial procedures for IPR enforcement, including injunctions, damages, and attorney fees. Parties may exclude patents and undisclosed information from this section. The border measures section focuses on effective border enforcement of IPR without creating barriers to legitimate trade, allowing customs authorities to suspend the release of suspect goods. Authorities can suspend the release of suspect goods on their own initiative or at the request of a right holder. Procedures are in place for in-transit goods or goods under customs control. Competent authorities must determine IPR infringement promptly and have the power to destroy infringing goods and impose penalties. They may also provide right holders with information on specific shipments. The Party must adopt procedures for determining IPR infringement, including the authority to order destruction of infringing goods and impose penalties. Criminal enforcement requires penalties for willful trademark counterfeiting or piracy, including imprisonment and fines. Authorities can also seize suspected counterfeit goods. The Party must provide penalties for copyright piracy on a commercial scale, including imprisonment and fines, and empower authorities to seize and forfeit counterfeit goods and related materials. The Party must provide penalties for copyright piracy on a commercial scale, including imprisonment and fines, and empower authorities to seize and forfeit counterfeit goods and related materials. Additionally, the digital enforcement section discusses obligations for enforcement of copyrights and related rights over digital networks, ensuring effective enforcement action against IPR infringement in the digital environment. The section on digital enforcement in the agreement ensures effective enforcement action against infringement of copyright and related rights over digital networks. It allows for penalties, seizure of counterfeit goods, and disclosure of identifying information related to infringement. Legal protection and remedies against infringement are also provided. The agreement ensures effective enforcement action against copyright infringement on digital networks, including penalties, seizure of counterfeit goods, and disclosure of identifying information. Legal protection and remedies against infringement are provided, along with the promotion of enforcement expertise and data collection by competent authorities. The chapter on enforcement practices focuses on methods used by Parties to apply IPR enforcement laws, promoting development of expertise, data collection on IPR infringement, and sharing information on border enforcement. The chapter on international cooperation in IPR enforcement emphasizes collaboration among Parties to address challenges in cross-border trade of counterfeit and pirated products. This includes promoting cooperation, sharing information, and raising public awareness on the importance of respecting IPR. Environmental considerations are also taken into account in the destruction of infringing goods. The international cooperation chapter in the agreement emphasizes collaboration among Parties to address challenges in cross-border trade of counterfeit and pirated products. It includes promoting cooperation, sharing information, assisting in capacity building, and avoiding duplication in international cooperation activities. An ACTA Committee is established to review the implementation and operation of the agreement. The institutional arrangement chapter of the agreement establishes an ACTA Committee to review implementation, proposed amendments, and terms of accession. The agreement remains open for signature until May 1, 2013, and will enter into force 30 days after the deposit of the sixth signature. The ACTA establishes a mechanism for consultations and remains open for signature until May 1, 2013. The agreement will enter into force after the sixth instrument of ratification is deposited. The U.S. conducted negotiations through the USTR, which leads trade agreements and consults with various government departments. The USTR, located in the EOP, leads U.S. trade agreement negotiations. It crafts policy with input from various agencies and advisory groups. The ACTA was negotiated as an executive agreement, aiming for consistency with U.S. law. The USTR negotiated the ACTA as an executive agreement, ensuring consistency with U.S. law. The agreement does not require changes to U.S. law for implementation and can be carried out under existing legal authority. Congressional involvement in the ACTA is based on constitutional powers related to foreign commerce and intellectual property rights. The United States can implement the ACTA under existing legal authority, similar to other trade agreements. Congressional involvement is rooted in the Constitution's powers over foreign commerce and intellectual property rights. Congress has the authority to regulate commerce with foreign nations and promote science and arts through copyright protection. The Constitution grants Congress the power to regulate foreign commerce and intellectual property rights. While Congress has not established a consultative role for itself in the ACTA, it has overseen the negotiation process and can monitor its implementation. The use of an executive agreement for the ACTA negotiations differs from past approaches to international trade negotiations on intellectual property rights. The United States has concerns about global IPR infringement, which can be costly for U.S. firms and consumers. IPR goals have traditionally been pursued through congressional-executive trade agreements, but the ACTA negotiations are conducted through an executive agreement, which is a departure from past approaches. The rise in piracy, especially in easily duplicated digital media, is fueled by low risks, minimal capital investment, and high profit margins. The costs of research and development are high for IPR-based industries, while infringement has low risks and high profit margins. Digital media duplication and internet usage contribute to piracy. Inadequate penalties in some countries fail to deter counterfeiting. U.S. trade policy emphasizes IPR protection due to economic, health, safety, and security concerns. The importance of IPR internationally is a key component of U.S. trade policy, driven by its significance to the economy and the negative consequences of counterfeiting and piracy. The economic, health, safety, and security rationales for U.S. participation in ACTA negotiations are highlighted, emphasizing the impact of counterfeiting and piracy on the economy and the role of IPR in promoting innovation and competitiveness. Adequate protection and enforcement of IPR are crucial for promoting innovation and competitiveness in the United States and other knowledge-based economies involved in ACTA negotiations. Counterfeiting and piracy cause significant revenue and trade losses for legitimate IPR-based industries, although quantifying these losses is challenging due to the secretive nature of IPR infringement. Tracking production and trade in counterfeit and pirated goods, especially digital media, is even more difficult. The economic losses from IPR infringement are substantial and challenging to quantify due to the secretive nature of the activity. Tracking production and trade in counterfeit goods, especially digital media, is difficult, with the internet further complicating data collection. Companies may be hesitant to disclose IPR infringement issues for fear of affecting product marketing. Some question the commercial rationale for the ACTA, noting that industry-generated estimates of losses may be biased. Some question the commercial rationale for the ACTA, as estimates of losses from IPR infringement may be biased. Critics argue that sales of pirated goods may not directly result in revenue losses for legitimate firms, as some consumers may not purchase the legitimate version at market price. Advocates of civil liberties highlight the importance of evaluating economic benefits of exceptions like "fair use" in copyright law. Public interest groups argue for a balanced approach to IPR protection. Some advocates argue that government discussions about ACTA should consider economic benefits of exceptions like "fair use" in copyright law. Critics believe that unbalanced IPR rules may hinder the free flow of information. Another reason for U.S. participation in ACTA is health and safety concerns related to counterfeit products. The U.S. participation in the ACTA negotiation is driven by concerns about health and safety risks posed by counterfeit products. While advocates argue that counterfeit goods can be substandard and dangerous, some public health experts believe that the focus on counterfeiting may not always align with actual health threats. Increasing IPR protection is seen as a way to incentivize innovation and research, but there are concerns about potential stifling of information flow. Counterfeiting and piracy can pose health and safety risks even if not infringing on IPR. Increasing IPR protection may hinder access to affordable medicines. U.S. involvement in ACTA also focuses on security concerns related to organized crime syndicates profiting from copyright infringement. Piracy may be linked to organized crime syndicates engaging in various illicit activities like drug smuggling and money laundering. The United States pursues IPR objectives through trade policy mechanisms, including multilaterally through the WTO and domestically through U.S. trade laws. The ACTA aims to enhance commitments in U.S. trade policy. The United States uses various trade policy mechanisms to pursue IPR objectives, including multilaterally through the WTO, regionally and bilaterally through FTAs, and domestically through U.S. trade laws. The ACTA aims to build on the TRIPS Agreement to address IPR challenges, such as issues with new technologies and piracy in digital media. The United States supports the negotiation of the ACTA to address gaps in the TRIPS Agreement related to IPR challenges, especially in new technologies and digital piracy. There are ongoing debates about the balance of rights in the TRIPS Agreement, with the U.S. seeking higher levels of protection in FTAs. The United States pursues higher levels of intellectual property rights protection in regional and bilateral FTAs, leading to ongoing debates about the balance of rights. Some IPR provisions in U.S. FTAs with Peru, Panama, and Colombia were revised after the Bipartisan Trade Agreement in 2007. U.S. FTAs have influenced the ACTA, with the U.S. aiming to model it on the IPR enforcement provisions in its FTAs. The Bipartisan Trade Agreement between congressional leadership and the Bush Administration led to revisions in some IPR provisions in U.S. FTAs with Peru, Panama, and Colombia, particularly in pharmaceutical-related IPR provisions. The U.S. FTAs have influenced the ACTA, with the U.S. aiming to expand stronger IPR commitments to a broader set of countries. The ACTA is a plurilateral agreement focused on intellectual property rights, different from traditional trade agreements. It aims to expand stronger IPR commitments to a broader set of countries and has sparked debates among stakeholders on process and substance concerns. The ACTA is a plurilateral agreement focused on intellectual property rights, sparking debates among stakeholders on process and substance concerns. U.S. business groups support the ACTA for stronger international IPR protection, while other groups like Internet service providers and civil society groups have expressed concerns about digital enforcement provisions. The ACTA is a plurilateral agreement focused on intellectual property rights. Stakeholders have differing views on the agreement, with U.S. business groups supporting it for stronger IPR protection, while Internet service providers and civil society groups have concerns about digital enforcement provisions. Other groups question the need for a new agreement to combat counterfeiting and piracy. The ACTA focuses on combating counterfeit goods, with varying definitions of "counterfeiting" referring to trademark infringement of physical goods. The ACTA initially focused on combating counterfeit goods, but as negotiations progressed, it broadened to include piracy, which refers to infringement of copyrights. The rationale behind creating a new agreement to combat counterfeiting and piracy is questioned by various stakeholders. The scope of the ACTA negotiations expanded to include piracy, which involves copyright infringement. Parties differed on including patents in civil enforcement, with the EU advocating for their inclusion to benefit industries like automotive and pharmaceuticals, while the US opposed it. The EU pushed for patents to be included in civil enforcement under ACTA to benefit industries like automotive and pharmaceuticals, but the US opposed it due to concerns about contradicting US patent law. The final ACTA text allows parties to exclude patents from civil enforcement, with the US stating it will do so. Countries are now deciding whether to exclude patents from their civil enforcement. The EU and US also disagreed on including trademarks in the digital realm. The ACTA allows countries to exclude patents from civil enforcement, with the US planning to do so. The EU and US had differing views on including trademarks in digital enforcement, with the EU supporting it and the US opposing it. The final ACTA text largely excludes trademark counterfeiting, focusing on copyright infringement over digital networks. It includes a provision allowing authorities to order online service providers to disclose information to identify subscribers involved in trademark or copyright infringement. The ACTA negotiation has raised concerns about transparency and public input. Critics argue that there was limited public transparency and consultation with consumer and public interest groups, while close consultation with right holders occurred. The level of secrecy in the negotiations has been noted by observers. Some critics assert that the ACTA negotiations lacked transparency and public input, with close consultation only with right holders. Observers noted unprecedented secrecy compared to other trade negotiations. Calls for enhanced transparency have been made by Members of Congress and stakeholders, urging USTR to allow public review and comment on ACTA proposals. Some Members of Congress and stakeholders have urged USTR to increase transparency in the ACTA negotiations. USTR defended the lack of public disclosure of draft text, stating it is customary during negotiations among sovereign states to maintain confidentiality to facilitate compromise and agreement. During the ACTA negotiations, negotiators agreed to keep proposals confidential to facilitate compromise and agreement. USTR shared a draft of the digital enforcement chapter with cleared advisors and industry groups under non-disclosure agreements. Transparency increased as negotiations progressed, with key elements summaries released publicly in 2009 and a draft text in 2010. The ACTA negotiation process became more transparent as it advanced, with key elements summaries released publicly in 2009 and a draft text in 2010. USTR also took steps to increase transparency by establishing a dedicated ACTA web page, releasing public agendas before each negotiating round, and consulting with Congress and stakeholders. In 2009, USTR increased transparency in the ACTA negotiation process by establishing a dedicated web page, releasing public summaries of issues, and consulting with Congress and stakeholders. USTR claims close collaboration with Congress and industry in developing the ACTA. USTR increased transparency in the ACTA negotiation process by consulting with Congress and stakeholders, including right holders, Internet intermediaries, and non-government organizations. The negotiation process also included a Federal Registrar notice for public comments and a public meeting with the Department of Commerce. Developing country participation in the ACTA was a subject of controversy. The ACTA negotiation process, led by the Department of Commerce, faced controversy due to the absence of developing country participation. Critics argue that the agreement was primarily negotiated among advanced industrialized countries, neglecting the interests of developing nations. Concerns were raised by China and India at WTO TRIPS Council meetings, stating that the ACTA could impact rights, obligations, and flexibilities in trade agreements, potentially limiting access to generic medicines and government resources for intellectual property rights enforcement. The ACTA, criticized for excluding developing countries, may weaken trade balance, limit access to generic medicines, and restrict government resources for intellectual property rights enforcement. Concerns were raised about the selection of countries involved in the ACTA, including those listed in the USTR's Special 301 Report for inadequate IPR protection. The ACTA negotiation assures that it respects public health declarations, civil liberties, and will not interfere with legitimate trade or fundamental rights. It will be consistent with the WTO TRIPS Agreement and will not hinder the cross-border transit of generic medicines. Participants reiterated that ACTA will not hinder the cross-border transit of legitimate generic medicines and patents will not be covered in the Section on Border Measures. The debate has focused on ACTA's potential impact on consumer privacy and the free flow of information, with concerns about digital enforcement provisions that could lead to Internet Service Providers terminating customers' accounts after repeated allegations of copyright infringement. The debate surrounds a provision that would require ISPs to terminate customers' Internet accounts after repeated allegations of copyright infringement, similar to a "three-strikes" law in France. Some argue that ISPs should not be responsible for enforcing intellectual property rights, while others believe it is necessary to combat online piracy. Critics are concerned about the potential for ISPs to filter communication and the low threshold for terminating Internet access. Some civil liberties groups are concerned about the burden on ISPs to terminate Internet access based on allegations of online piracy. The ACTA aims to address online piracy with provisions similar to SOPA and the PROTECT IP Act. The final ACTA text does not include a "three-strikes" rule or "notice-and-takedown" rules, but requires ISPs to disclose information to right holders. The final ACTA text does not include a "three-strikes" rule or "notice-and-takedown" rules. Instead, it requires ISPs to disclose information to right holders for identifying subscribers allegedly involved in infringement. The ACTA aims to avoid creating barriers to legitimate activity and preserve fundamental principles like freedom of expression, fair process, and privacy.
